newsitem.title: USA: Fidelity fixed-income manager Gray resigns.
newsitem.headline: Fidelity fixed-income manager Gray resigns.

text.p: Fidelity Investments said fixed income fund manager Michael Gray, who managed or co-managed nine different mutual funds, has decided to leave the company to start his own investment management firm.
"He's going to take some time off and then he's going to start his own investment management firm specializing in fixed income," Fidelity spokeswoman Teri Kilduff told Reuters.
"Michael has done a fine job for shareholders. We are sorry to see him leave but we respect his decision," she said.
David O'Leary, president of Alpha Equity Research, said he estimates that Gray was responsible for around $10 billion in assets at the nine funds.
Gray's exit, which follows last week's announcement that fund managers Larry Greenberg and Andrew Offit were also quitting, was not over a salary dispute, O'Leary said.
Many of the fund managers have fled to smaller, boutique firms where they have greater control in managing assets, he said.

"It's got nothing to do with compensation," he told Reuters. "They are going to small firms where they have more flexibility in managing money and you don't have the pressure of living in a fish bowl."
Don Dion, publisher of the newsletter Fidelity Independent Advisor, said he believed compensation was the main issue for the exodus.
"We're pretty concerned and we think (Fidelity Chairman) Ned Johnson is going to have to open up his wallet and pay these people more," he said.
As well, the mutual fund industry has exploded over the past year and, with the stock market continuing to set record highs, firms are scouting for experienced managers, he said.
"If you're a head-hunting firm and you're trying to get someone, you got 400 people to call at Fidelity," Dion said.
The loss of Greenberg, who managed four funds totalling about $21 billion in assets, was a tough blow for the mutual fund company, analysts said.
Earlier this week, to fill the positions for Greenberg and Offit, Fidelity announced a shakeup, changing the managers of nearly 20 mutual funds.
Kilduff said Fidelity would name replacements for Gray at a later date.
Gray managed the fixed-income portions of the $11.2 billion Asset Manager fund, the $3.4 billion Asset Manager: Growth fund, and the $589 million Asset Manager: Income fund.
A 14-year veteran with the company, he also managed the fixed-income assets of the $4.1 billion Balanced fund and he co-managed three of Fidelity's VIP funds.
Gray could not be reached for comment.
